text: <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein

<extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( also known as <extra_id_0> TNFAIP3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is a <extra_id_0> ubiquitin-editing protein <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> that negatively regulates <extra_id_0> NF-kappaB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent gene expression in response to different immune - activating stimuli , including <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , IL-1 and antigens , and the triggering of TLRs and the nucleotide - binding oligomerisation domain - containing 2 receptor ( reviewed in [ 37 ] ) .

<extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is believed to inhibit NF-kappaB function by deubiquitinating specific NF-kappaB signalling molecules , such as <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> RIP2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> MALT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which disrupts specific protein-protein interactions [ 38-41 ] ( Figure 1 ) .

Recently , the disruption of interactions between E2 ubiquitin conjugating enzymes ( <extra_id_0> Ubc13 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Ubc5hc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and E3 ubiquitin ligases ( <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> TRAF2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> cIAP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) were described as another important mechanism used by <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to downregulate NF-kappaB signalling [ 42 ] .

The association of <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> with its targets requires specific ubiquitin - binding adaptor proteins , including <extra_id_0> A20-binding inhibitor of NF-kappaB (ABIN) 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Tax1-binding protein 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 43-46 ] .
Next to its role in suppressing NF-kappaB activation , <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is also a strong inhibitor of apoptosis , at least in some cell types .
The mechanisms by which <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> regulates apoptotic signalling , however , are still elusive .

<extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient mice spontaneously develop multiorgan inflammation and cachexia and die within 2 weeks of birth , illustrating the potent anti-inflammatory function of this molecule [ 46 ] .

<extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient cells are also more susceptible to <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated apoptosis , confirming its role as an antiapoptotic protein .

We recently showed that mice specifically lacking <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in intestinal epithelial cells exhibit increased susceptibility to experimental colitis due to the hypersensitivity of their intestinal epithelial cells to <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced apoptosis , confirming <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as a major antiapoptotic protein in the intestinal epithelium [ 47 ] .

Two independent studies showed that mice lacking <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in B cells develop autoimmunity due to hyperactive NF-kappaB responses in B cells leading to unrestricted B-cell survival [ 48 , 49 ] .

<extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression has been observed in several cell types that play important roles in the pathophysiology of RA , such as fibroblasts , synoviocytes and lymphocytes .

Interestingly , <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression is itself regulated by NF-kappaB [ 50 ] , implicating <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the negative feedback regulation of NF-kappaB signalling .

Recently , intra-articular injection of an <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - expressing adenovirus was shown to reduce the severity of synovial inflammation and joint destruction in a mouse model of collagen - induced arthritis , even in untreated joints , in both a prophylactic and therapeutic setting .

<extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in synovial tissue was associated with inhibition of NF-kappaB activity and decreased levels of <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , soluble <extra_id_0> RANKL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> monocyte chemo-attractant protein 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and IL-17 , suggesting that <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induces a protective effect in collagen - induced arthritis mice through suppression of NF-kappaB activation and NF - kappaB - dependent gene expression [ 51 ] .

Because <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are known to mediate synovitis , pannus formation , and erosion of cartilage and bone in RA , the decreased serum levels of <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - transduced mice might explain the beneficial effects in the clinical , pathological , and radiological findings .
This study also demonstrated that <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> overexpression leads to a decrease in the number of activated osteoclasts in joint tissue .
<extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> might therefore minimise joint destruction through decreasing the osteoclast number and activity .

It will be interesting to analyse in future the susceptibility of conditional knockout mice that lack <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in specific cell types such as synovial fibroblasts , macrophages , dendritic cells , B cells or T cells .

Importantly , several SNPs in the human <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> locus have been associated with increased susceptibility to development of autoimmune pathologies ( reviewed in [ 52 ] ) .

Several genome-wide association studies also revealed a clear association between mutations in the <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> locus in the 6q23 chromosome and susceptibility to RA [ 52 ] .

Although the identified variants are not located in a gene , they are thought to influence <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as its nearest gene ( ~150 kb downstream of <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , probably by the presence of potential regulatory DNA elements in this region .

As <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is required for termination of <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced signals , and <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is the primary inflammatory <extra_id_0> cytokine <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA , these findings reveal <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as a candidate susceptibility locus for RA .
How these variants affect normal <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activity and how they cause RA , however , remain unclear .

Recently , Elsby and colleagues functionally evaluated in vitro the regulatory ability of RA - associated SNP variants on <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity , and could show repressed <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcription for some of the SNPs investigated [ 53 ] .
It will be of interest to identify the actual causal variants and to elucidate the functional consequences of these variants .
In this context , knockin mice for the corresponding <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> SNPs , combined with mouse models for RA , will be very valuable tools .
